Although she is not designated his wife, they appear together in one inscription in the Elijah cave, where often family members are listed together.

We assume that a man and a woman mentioned together on the same inscription in Elijah’s Cave are man and wife, but see below, n. 5.
Jewishness suggested based on husband’s name, but see next note.
The reconstruction of this name as female is based on the fact that most persons mentioned in Elijah’s Cave inscriptions are man and wife, but this is not decisive. This could be a male.
On the dating of the Greek inscriptions in Elijah’s Cave see Appendix 3.1.

According to this document, she left her property to the Jewish community in Antioch in Syria. This rather suggests that she was Jewish, but the evidence is not unequivocal.
This legal decision is dated, see Introduction 7.1.

state.note: Optata (1), wife of a soldier of Emessa

person.note: In Latin – Emes(enorum) (in Syria).
Her husband is described in this inscription as “mili(tis) de num(ero) regi(oru) Emes(enorum) Iudeoru(m)” (a soldier from the troop of the Royal Emesene Jews), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.4, p. 30.

Caesarea was a mixed city. Unless clearly attested, Jewishness cannot be taken for granted, see Introduction, 6.2.1.2. Here the names may suggest descent from the Herodian family, see also vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.5, p. 53.

Germer-Durand suggests reading Justina. Di Segni, “Εἱς θεός,” 101 reads ̓Ιουστᾳ. On the fall of the identifying suffix in Latin names see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.4.1.
Ancient city, north of Tel Aviv.

The inscription is accompanied by the exclamation Εἱς θεὸς̔ ζῶν (the one living God) which could be Samaritan, but see Introduction 6.1.6.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

The amulet is bilingual – Greek and Samaritan (in the Samaritan script, see Introduction 6.1.3).
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.
See above, n. 2.
In Greek – τεχνίτη. On such designations see Introduction 3.1.3.3.
The inscription contains the formula Εἵς θεος (one God), and bears no Christian markers, see Introduction 6.1.6.

Jarry translates ̓Ιωανα Μαρκιανη τεχνίτη ἐπηησαν with „Jean et Marcien mâitres d’ oeuvre ont fait.” According to him the orthography is “extrêmement fantaisiste,” interpreting the names as those of two males. However, this is unlikely.
The inscription is dated according to the Seleucid era, see Introduction 7.5.4.1.

On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, p. 17. On the interchange of τ and θ see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.6, p. 16. On the Greek feminine suffix see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2.1, p. 18.
In Greek – ζήσασα ἔτη ο ́. On such details see vol. 3, Introduction 3.1, p. 21.
The inscription is neither specifically Christian, nor undoubtedly pagan. Since the Zoar cemetery includes Jewish tombstones, this one could also be Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.1.
Because so many of the inscriptions from Zoar are dated, it is easy to date the others approximately, see Introduction 7.5.2.3.

In Greek - Καὶ τοῦτο ο̓ περὶ τῆς ἐνταῦθα λέγω συαγωγῆς μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ τῆς ἐν Δάφνη. πονερότερον γὰρ ἐκεῖ τὸ βάραθρον ὅ δὴ καλοῦσι Ματρώνης (And I say this not only about the synagogue here in the city but also about the one in Daphne [near Antioch in Syria T.I.]). For the pit of destruction there, which they call Matrona’s, is even more evil).
Since the synagogue is named after her, I assume she was a wealthy Jewish woman who contributed toward its foundation.
The synagogue designated after her was active during the life of Johannes Chrysostomus. These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
The suggested reading is mine. CIJ read Μα[ι]ρώνας, but this makes no sense. For this form see vol. 3, Matrona (3), p. 599.
Jewishness may be suggested based on father’s name, but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.6.7, p. 52. The region was not particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.1.6.
I have inserted these dates when editors claimed the composition or find was Byzantine, see Introduction 7.5.5.
See above, n. 6.

Reading reconstructed by editor, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.1, p. 11. On such transliterations see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 17. כ and ק are interchangeable in the transliteration of the Greek κ/ξ or the Latin c/x see e.g. in vol. 1, under Alexander (19) and (20) G/M, p. 258.
The inscription is in the Samaritan script, see Introduction 6.1.3.
In Latin – mili(tis) de num(ero) regi(orum) Emes(enorum) (a soldier from the troop of the Royal Emesenes) Emesa is in Syria.
Her husband is described in this inscription as “Emes(enorum) Iudeoru(m)” (of the Royal Emesene Jews), see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.4, p. 30.

This law is repeated in a legal text called Summa Perusina of the early 7th century, where she is designated Cornelia Aquila, see A. Linder, The Jews in the Legal Sources of the Early Middle Ages (Detroit 1997) 210 (no. 412). On Aquila as a male name see e.g. under Aquila L/M, in vol. 1, p. 327.
According to this document, she left her property to the Jewish community in Antioch in Syria. This rather suggests that she was Jewish, but the evidence is not unequivocal.
This legal decision is dated.
